abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Protection
            Project for El Salvador were as follows: the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory, all other ratings are not
            applicable since the operation is cancelled.  The
            Bank's Board approved the loan on October 27, 2005 but
            it was not signed or made effective within 18 months of
            Board approval. The Bank team had appropriately identified
            political polarization as a source of risk for the loan to
            be ratified and deployed all possible mitigation actions;
            while the political environment at the time of Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS) and loan processing provided
            evidence suggesting that this risk was manageable. Some
            lessons learned are in the areas of: growing political
            polarization regarding the role of multilateral development
            banks in Latin America, (ii) redefining Bank cooperation
            strategies (in addition to loan financing), management of
            project exogenous issues, and (iv) the important role of
            information and outreach in Bank's work.

9095497.trustfund:
TF030667-JAPAN CTF - FY05 GENERAL: LAC
            (ALL COUNTRIES IN LATIN AMERICA AND THE C,TF053765-PHRD-EL SALVADOR: SOCIAL

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on Social
            Protection Project in El Salvador. One of the most critical
            challenges for development faced by El Salvador was to
            strengthen the poor populations. The project supported
            Conditional Cash Transfer Program, which encouraged
            extremely poor households to send the five to fifteen years
            old children to preschool and primary education. It expanded
            the supply of basic health and nutrition services,
            strengthened community-based health care interventions to
            prevent chronic malnutrition amongst the poor. It ensured
            that all target household members were incorporated into the
            vital statistics bureau and have the necessary personal
            identification documents to access basic public services.

6726380.trustfund:
TF053765-PHRD-EL SALVADOR: SOCIAL
            PROTECTION AND LOCAL DEVELOPMENT (FISDL),TF030667-JAPAN CTF - FY05 GENERAL: LAC
            (ALL COUNTRIES IN LATIN AMERICA AND THE C

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Protection Project for El
            Salvador will improve the education, health, and nutrition
            of Salvadoran children living in the rural areas of 100
            poorest municipalities. Project components: (i) This
            component will support the implementation of a conditional
            cash transfer program to encourage extremely poor families
            to send their children 5-15 years old to pre-school and
            primary education, maintain the full immunization package in
            children younger than 5 years, and regularly monitor the
            growth and development of children aged 0-24 months. (ii)
            This component will support the expansion of the existing
            basic package of maternal and child health services, and the
            strengthening of nutritional interventions. (iii) This
            component will support the National Civil Registry (RNPN) in
            expanding legal access to basic education and health
            services in the 100 municipalities targeted under the Red
            Solidaria. (iv) The Project also will support the
            implementation of the Red Solidaria Program through the
            establishment and strengthening of an appropriate
            institutional structure.

repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Social Protection and Local
            Development Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Protection and Local
            Development Project will support the Government of El
            Salvador in improving access to basic services of the
            poorest Salvadoran families, by helping them to invest in
            the education, health, and nutrition of their children.
            Salvadoran Indigenous People are descendants of the Pupils,
            a nomadic tribe of the Nahua of Central Mexico, the
            Mesoamerican Lenca and the South-American Chibcha. From the
            beginning of the Spanish conquest in El Salvador, the
            Indigenous and the Spaniards lived in the same areas. Racial
            mixing known as mestizaje began in the XVI century. With the
            development of the indigo plantations in the early XVII
            century, many indigenous villages were destroyed, and many
            were forced to farm and work on these plantations. In the
            infamous la matanza, masacre of 1932, 50,000 indigenous were
            killed in retaliation of an indigenous upheavel to protest
            government policies. After this event, the indigenous began
            to hide their traditions and to assimilate to the dominant
            ladino society quietly.
